risinfo.chaptertitle: 3. Presenting Problem, History of Presenting Problem, and Social History

sect1.title: Preliminary Factors to Consider
sect1.para: Before diving into the process and components of a clinical interview, there are a few preliminary factors clinicians should consider.

sect2.title: Interviewing Efficiently
sect2.para: In the current environment of limited reimbursable hours by insurers, clinicians must prioritize efficiency during the clinical interview interview and assessment process. To streamline the process, clinicians may consider using biopsychosocial self-report screening measures to obtain preliminary information on the client’s symptom patterns. In cases where clients deny a symptom or problem on a screener, basic questioning during the clinical interview is adequate to obtain information about symptom patterns, allowing more time for in-depth exploration of relevant concerns concerns . If, after completing the initial interview, the clinician realizes that more information is needed, follow-up questions can be asked in additional meetings with the client.

sect2.title: Interview with the Intake Report and Feedback in Mind
Monitor Cues for Underreporting, Overreporting, and Additional Information
sect2.para: Throughout the interview, the clinician should be mindful of cues indicating the client may be either underreporting or overreporting symptoms and listen for opportunities to obtain additional information. Detecting underreporting or overreporting requires the clinician to interview tactfully with follow-up on inconsistent information, which can help ensure the information is reliable and valid. This may involve asking follow-up questions for inconsistent information and building rapport with the client to facilitate their motivation for accurate disclosure. Clinicians should monitor for signs of secondary gain, such as seeking a diagnosis for access to medication or disability benefits. Clients may also exhibit non-verbal behavior that may signal discomfort with a specific topic of conversation. They may also organically mention information from other sources (e. g., referring to prior medical or psychiatric diagnoses or previous testing). Though it may interrupt the clinician’s assessment assessment flow, it can be more effective to ask about this information now, followed by a return to the previous point in the interview after a brief exploration of the new information.
